text:
[INAUDIBLE] Good morning and thank you for joining us
for this public webinar event,

"Future Thailand: Innovation and Education
and Workforce Development", presented by the Stanford
Thailand Research Consortium.

My name is Matt Harvey and I am
the Senior Director of Global Initiatives with the Stanford Center
for Professional Development

here at Stanford University in California. As we begin, I'd like to remind all of you
that live translation in the Thai language

is available for this event, which you can access inside Zoom
by selecting the interpretation icon

and selecting Thai
as your preferred language. You may need to be using the latest
version of Zoom to access this function.

However, please note
that following this event, we will be releasing a video of this talk which will include Thai subtitling
for future reference.

I would like to thank all of you
for joining us today and to also extend our support
and good wishes for health

to all of you
and your families in Thailand as we continue to navigate
the evershifting challenges

of confronting
the COVID-19 global pandemic. And for today's event,
I want to express specific appreciation

to the inaugural community
of Innovative Teaching Scholars from universities across Thailand
joining us today.

Your work and efforts
are deeply appreciated and will serve as a light to guide others
in creating transformational experiences

for your peer educators, institutions and for Thai students
and graduates.

Additionally, I would like to express
my gratitude to our Stanford faculty and the consortium member companies
and the key executives

who have been able to be generous
in offering their time with us today, across two continents, to share their perspectives
on issues of innovation in education

and workforce development. Throughout today's event,
our team will post notes, links and quotes

in the public chat. However, if you have a question
for our panelists or have a technical support question,

you may write that in Thai or English
in the Q&A function in Zoom. Our team members,
both at Stanford and in Thailand,

will do our best to assist you. For today's event, we will feature a short discussion on
the Innovative Teaching Scholars program

with both its Stanford faculty leader and a participating
scholar in the program, followed by our panel discussion
with the Stanford faculty and executives,

and finally, a question and answer session
where our panelists will be available to answer questions you submit
through the Q&A function in Zoom,

and we encourage you to do so. To provide all of you
with some context about this work,

the Stanford Thailand Research Consortium
supports research in social, economic, and technological development areas
key to Thailand's future success

and aligned
with Stanford faculty expertise. The consortium is
part of Stanford's Office of the Vice Provost and Dean of Research

and is actively managed by our faculty
steering committee and our organization, the Stanford Center
for Professional Development.

The consortium has over a dozen research
and education projects underway, focusing on a diverse range of topics,

including examples such as using artificial intelligence
to support improved elderly care,

reducing deforestation,
and aiding smallhold farmers in Thailand's Nan province,

creating organizational insights
and capacity around leveraging new models and training methods for entrepreneurship
and innovation skills,

studying factors and interventions for
improving the wellness for Thai citizens, and our topic for today, building capacity
and innovation to improve education.

This work would not be possible
without the generous support of the member companies of
the Stanford Thailand Research Consortium,

AIS, AP, and Kasikorn Bank. We are very grateful for their continued
support and engagement for this work,

which aims to benefit all of Thai society. Also, the work of the Stanford Thailand
Research Consortium benefits immensely

from our ability to work
with our talented colleagues at SEAC. Their dedicated team continue
to support our research teams

to do vital and important work
that has benefits to Thailand, particularly against the backdrop
of the global pandemic.

I want to express
my deep admiration and appreciation to the entire SEAC organization and team,

and I am happy to introduce SEAC's Managing Director
and Chief Capability Officer,
Arinya Talerngsri, to say a few words. Arinya. For nearly 30 years,

my team and I have worked to improve
educational opportunities to empower Thais.

SEAC is proud to
contribute to this project with the amazing faculty from Stanford,

three of Thailand's most
forward thinking companies and truly dedicated Thai educators.

Thailand must do so much more
to prepare its youngest generations for a competitive workforce.

For Thailand's economy and its people to regain its competitive edge, more youngest generation
will need to be better equipped.

Doing so involves expanding access
to quality development services,

especially in rural areas. AIS, KASIKORN Bank and AP Thailand
are selflessly contributing

to the future of our education system. The support from these three organizations
and the dedication of the Thai educators

who have joined our effort are at the forefront
of an important transformation,
they show what is possible in empowering teachers and students for a better future.

As a fellow educator,
I am very much looking forward to listening and learning today.
So let's get started.

Thank you, Arinya. We would now like to open
our official portion of the program and introduce you to
the Innovative Teaching Scholars Program

to set the stage and context
for our panel discussion. To do so, I'm proud to introduce
our moderator for today's discussions,

Leticia Britos Cavagnaro, Adjunct Professor in the Hasso Plattner
Institute of Design at Stanford.

Along with serving as the faculty lead of
the Innovative Teaching Scholars Program, she is co-director
of the University Innovation Fellows,

a Stanford d.School program
which empowers students to be co-designers of their education in collaboration with faculty
and leaders at their schools.

Leticia was Deputy Director
of the National Center for Engineering Pathways to Innovation,
or Epicenter, here in the United States,

and has worked with hundreds
of educators and students of all ages, as well as corporate
and non-profit leaders
in the US and internationally. Leticia. Thank you, Matt, and welcome everyone.

Matt shared those organizations
and individuals
who have made this possible, and Khun Arinya shared the why. Why is this initiative important?

I want to build on that
and tell you a little bit about the how and what we did in this program.

The Innovative Teaching Scholars, an initiative of
the Stanford Thailand Research Consortium,

was a professional development opportunity
for university educators.

And it was quite a unique opportunity. If we are to transform
the higher education system
to support the young people who are going to build the future,

we need to empower and prepare
those who are in the front lines,

and those are the teachers. In this program, we selected 50 educators
from 9 leading Thai universities,

and they joined us
back in September of 2020 for a very intensive program where
they met weekly with a teaching team,
and they explored different approaches, innovative approaches to teaching,

supported by research, supported
by what we know about how we learn best,

and about the skills and mindsets
that we need to give our students

to build an innovation based
economy and society.

Just an hour ago, we're very proud
to say that 47 scholars,
47 educators, graduated from the program. It was nine months of hard work,

of trying new things
and all in the benefit of the students.

The goal has always been
what difference does this make
in what the students can become not only in terms of passing tests,

but in terms of what they can do
when they are out in the real world,

when they're out in the workforce, because we need them
to think as innovators

if they're going to build the future. But instead of me just telling more
about the program,

we have invited today
one of those scholars who just graduated from these
nine months of hard work and study

to tell you a little bit
about her experience in the program.

So I'm going to invite
Professor Nutsuda Sumonsiri to join me here and tell us a little bit
about her experience in the program.
Nutsuda, thank you so much for joining us. Tell us a little bit about you,

your university,
your position, what you teach.

Thank you, Leticia, first for inviting me. And I'm an Associate Professor
in food science and technology

from King Mongkut's University
of Technology North Bangkok. Mostly I have most of my students
are undergraduate students

and I teach biology
for the 1st year students,

food quality and control and food quality
evaluation for the 3rd year students,

and fermented food technology
and food industrial management

for the 4th year students. So I have a variety of students
that join my class.

Great and Nutsuda represents
just one of the many disciplines.

This program had professors
across many different disciplines,

from biology to media studies,
languages, mathematics, you name it.

Because we think that
there are some principles about how we teach that are valuable
across disciplines.

And it's about the vision of what we think that how we can add value
to the growth of our students.

Nutsuda, tell us what value did the ITS
program add to your practice as educator?

What did you get from it? Actually, since I have taught
for almost nine years already,
so my teaching is just like a routine. Just give a lecture.

I give my students exercises
and just do the exam.

This program actually
got me out of my safe zone,

so it's like I can try new things, something that I would like
to try in the past,

but I don't have time
or opportunity to try, but this program gives me new ideas,

techniques and tools to help
my students learn more. And actually, I love
when I can share with my friends,

my colleagues, my learning partner,
and we can share experience.

And actually I learned
that we face in the same situation.

And I get somebody to work
with me throughout this program.

And what you mentioned
is really important, and is something else that I want
to share about the program,

that this is not just a workshop,
just a program and it's over,

but it's really the cultivation
of a community of practice

of innovative educators
like Professor Nutsuda, who are sharing with one another,

are inspiring one another, are sharing their struggles, are sharing what works and what
doesn't work and are inspiring others.

So we might start with a small group
if you think about 47 educators

considering the number
of university educators across Thailand, but we are confident that
they are going to be an inspiration.

They are going to be a reference
for other educators out there, and that is the goal of the program.

Nutsuda, tells us,
you mentioned your students. How do your students benefit
from you being an innovative educator?

Actually, I also learned
from my students from this program.

We have reflection
every time after we do experiments

and we try new things with our students. What I can feel is that my students
enjoy my activities, enjoy my class.

And I think all the activities
I have tried

makes them stimulated
to learn more effectively.

And actually, I like the one
that my favorite activities are

the exploration before explanation. It's like I have my students who explore
what they will learn before teaching them.
And I think they learn something more, and they have freedom to learn.
That's great. Thank you so much for sharing and thank you so much for being here.

We're going to move on now
to introduce the other panelists. Thank you so much, again, Nutsuda.

It was great
that you could share your perspective. I'd like to introduce
the rest of the panelists

that will be sharing
their perspectives today. We have first Professor Sheri Sheppard.

She is the Richard Weiland Professor
in the Stanford School of Engineering.

She is also the co-director
of the Center for Design Research

and she is
an incredibly innovative educator and researcher in education.

So it has been a great pleasure for me
to work with Sheri in this program,

and I'm hoping that she will share
some of the insights that she has gained. I would like to say that this
has been an action research project,

not just understanding what doesn't work, but trying new things and figuring out
how can we scale those things.

How can we learn from what we are trying. It has been a great collaboration
and we'll hear from Sheri in that respect.
We also have Kantima Lerlertyuttitham, Khun Kantima

from the Chief Human Resources
Officer at AIS.

We also have Ruangroj Poonpol, the Chairman of Kasikorn Business
Technology Group. Khun Krating, welcome.

We also have Vittakarn Chandavimol, the Chief Corporate Strategy
& Creation Officer at AP Thailand.

Welcome, Khun Ming. Thank you for being here. Thank you all for being here and apologies
if I mispronounced your names.
I was trying to do my best with that. I have a series of questions for you,

and I'd like for us
to really have a conversation. So if I direct a question to someone

and someone else wants to contribute,
please do. Let's make this a true,
productive conversation.

But I'd like to start
by going to the future, inviting you all to go
to the future with this panel,

because as we know, things change at an
incredibly fast pace these days, it seems.

So the future will be here
before you know it, right? Or as a famous quote says,
"The Future is Already Here." It's just not evenly distributed. So let's think about the future.

And my question to each one of our
panelists from the consortium companies

and of course, Sheri as well, is, what are skills and knowledge that
you envision will become more important

for employees in your companies
10 years from now

and which might be
less important in that future?

Khun Krating, can I ask you
to get us started with that?
Hi.

-Sorry, Leticia. Can you repeat--
-Yes, of course, I'll repeat the question. What skills and knowledge do you envision
that will become important

for employees at your company
10 years from now? So let's go to the future. I think basically I call it
the human machine interaction.

I think it's very important
because in the next 10 years, I think we are all aware that AI will be the most important
technology of our times,

and we need to learn
to work with AI, I think. And because in my company we apply AI
in every single aspect of our operation

from end to end automation, even in software development, because even
we are trying to work with them,

actually, with Stanford as well, on developing an AI that basically
can create a program itself.

So I think we need to learn
how to work with machine. That's number one. You are either the one
to create a machine,

train the machine,
or work with the machine, or you will be basically
commanded by the machines, which definitely
you do not want to do that.

And in order to do that, I think you basically need
to develop technology caution.

I think technology caution
is very important basically to understand technology, how to apply technology
because every single company

and every single aspect of our lives
will be impacted by technology. And then I think we shouldn't lose
the touch of the string of human being.

Basically the things like empathy, agility, and ability to learn
and unlearn and relearn. I think.

And I think recently
especially during this time, I think in the next 10 years, I call it
the age of continuous disruption,

every single exponential technology
will converge and then creating exponential
changes every single year.

So I think we need to learn how to adapt, be agile, be resilient, learn to work with the machine
and definitely, I think, an ability

to continuously renew ourselves. I think for me that's more important
than the subject matter knowledge,

because at KBTG we have
a lot of programs to reskill employees. So I think when they come, they are smart,

they work hard and they have
a good attitude, they can definitely be, for example, I think one of the best

data scientist, he's basically
a Petroleum engineering student and the best business analyst
for our core banking.
Basically, they have business education, they don't have any technology background.

When they, like, with the right attitude and ability to learn and then also ready
to challenge the status quo, I think,

it's kind of like
more like a skill and competency that like subject method and knowledge.

Great. You covered a lot there. I just want to kind of summarize
some of the things you mentioned,

empathy, the ability to learn and relearn, the ability to adapt, the ability and mindset
to challenge the status quo,

I think that's wonderful. Khun Kantima, what is your perspective
in this regard?

What are the skills, knowledge, mindsets that will be important 10 years from now
in your company and your field?

I would say Krating
took all the important points. But anyway, besides the digital
technology all those types of things.

I think that the communication will play an important role,
but in a different way.

In the past we have everyone
sit in the office, working together, those type of things.

But the pandemic made things change. You see that the communication
will play an important role,

especially when people change
their working style, and besides that is the active learning.

I think that's very important because
the responsibility of the career growth

and skill set adaptability
also depends on, I will say

in the past it's more on organization
side that provided the stuff,

but now it's no longer. I think that's 50/50 responsibilities
because the company or the organization

can provide access in general
to all those knowledge. But the active learning skill is something
that the employee need to bear in mind

that they have to keep themselves adapted at every time,
you see that things change nowadays,

when things change,
they change faster and more, I would say we're talking about,
especially in Thailand,

we're talking about digital transformation which is, I would say, that is huge bigger
than change management.

You change your DNA, you change the way. and besides that I think that we need
to focus on the culture change.

So people have to have the abilities
to adapt to change because whatever the company believe,

whatever the education system believes
is no longer be the same anymore.

It will change faster. So ability that they can
adapt to change is very important.

Last but not least is the leadership. I think leadership
need to change, big change,

especially in Asian contexts, because whatever we believe,
that respectful and all of those,
we need to give the rooms, we need to give the room and the stage, you know, the new generation,

they need the spotlight on themselves
because they have all those skill sets. So the leader need
to adapt ourselves a lot
in terms of changing the way we think, changing the way we're leading the team.

So those are the things
that I need to address.

Last point is
what we see as less important. I think that I would say that
I could not say is less important,

but it will change faster,
all the knowledge, all the technology will move very fast.

So that's how I see. Thank you for sharing that. And you mentioned the importance of
culture change in the role of leadership.

And I will remind everyone
that we have been-- my colleague Meenu

has been adding some highlights, some quotes from the responses
that you just heard to provoke questions.

We really want questions from all
of you who are listening to this panel,

and you can add your questions
at any time in the Q&A box. We will address
those questions at the end,

but please add them. And we're adding these summaries, these quote from the panelists
to get you curious

and get you asking questions.
So please do. So Khun Ming what is your perspective
in this regard?

What is the future in your company? To be the third one
to answer this question,

I think I need to
is kind of pretty much similar to what Khun Kantima and Khun Krating mentioned.

But I would like to summarize
into two big things, the future skill that we need.

The first one is cognitive flexibility. At the speed of the business world
has been escalated,

driven by the technologies
and new inventions. everyone has to have the ability and be ready to change.

This means that
they have to embrace changes, improve ability to learn
and understanding the unknown

or evolving market that they are facing, be able to adapt your decisions and
actions to the complex problems quickly.

With this ability, they can enjoy
and have the confidence to have fresh and innovative ideas.

And I think some of the example,
very basic example of the cognitive flexibility
is in the workplace
is that the people who are comfortable

with the job locations to the new area. They're open to learn and they're open
to move to the uncomfortable zone.

And this is the first one
that I think is quite critical when we are looking to see in the future.

And the second one everybody
talks about is social skills. This includes emotional intelligence,

skill to collaborate with others
and communication or negotiation.

It would make people different from
and better than robots in the future.

As mentioned in the next 10 years, we will see a lot of job automations
and robot replacing our current jobs.

However, recognizing
the colleague special or verbal explanations,
emphasizing the root causes

or adjust behavior accordingly would be
very complex accordingly for the robot.

That means we can manage expectations from our frame expressions ability
to effectively collaborate with

or work with the multi discipline
is also crucial, as the future problems
will be more complex

and need different knowledges
or skills to solve them. And for the part
of the less important skill,

I think other skills for
the existing technology. In my area,

like in the architectural designs area, two dimensional AutoCAD that skill
will be obsolete in the near future.

We can replace like
three dimensional building skill. These are my comments.

Yeah. Thank you so much
for adding so much nuance to something that is so fascinating.

If we look
from the perspective of the workforce,

and you mentioned
the importance of social emotional skills, and let's look now
from the perspective of the university.

So, Sheri, as a university educator who has also worked
in industry for many years,

what are some gaps that you see between what the students get
as learning experiences
and the skills or the challenges they face when they enter the workforce?

And you're muted, Sheri. I would say one related
to who scopes the work.

When you take a university class, you're given a syllabus
and a set of assignments with due dates,

and you move methodically through a course and you're done with the course
at the end of a semester.

Real work doesn't come in semester chunks, and your assignments
may include the emergency thing

that needs to get done tomorrow, and a longer range project. And one of the things I think students are
not well equipped to do is time management

in terms of keeping all those balls going and along with all the communications
you need to be doing

with various team members, I would say another challenge
is academic teams,

even on design projects are made up so students
can sit around the table and work together on designing something.
Real design often doesn't happen that way, especially with distributed teams, and you may join a team for a few weeks.

You may join another team for months. And so how do we manage
those relationships

and really get to know what the project
is, what you can contribute, get to know the other people on it,

and then realize
you'll move on to another team. I would say another thing is
students learning what is it to lead?

And it may be that you're the person
with a big title, but in a team project,

how you take a part of it
and actually take ownership while still collaborating with others?

And so I would say that's another area
that many academics struggle with in terms of how to give students
those kind of experiences.

But I would say in general, all of those kind of skills that we'd
like to see students to be better at

really shift us away from the old paradigm
of a teacher centered classroom where you have an expert
whose giving his or her lecture

and students are copying dutifully down
the notes and maybe processing them later.

They really call
for I would say a messier classroom in terms of the kind of prompt that's given.

And I really appreciated the idea
of experiencing before explaining,

having students work together. So it requires all of us
to think, in new ways,

what is a university classroom? That's beautiful. And if we remember
what Professor Nutsuda mentioned

when I asked her about
her experience with the program, she said, "I'm a learner. I learn from my students as well."

And I think that developing that attitude, having educators that see themselves
as learners is what we need

to inspire the students
and send them the message that you're not going to
learn all that there is to learn

and then graduate and be ready. Learning is something
that you will continue,
and as Khun Krating mentioned earlier as well, it's about also unlearning and relearning.

It's something that, a mindset
that they really need to acquire. And that was
one of the goals of the program

I have a question about-- Sheri mentioned some
of the skills of time management,

communication with team members, collaboration in teams that maybe
the universities are not doing

such a great job of preparing
the students with.
Any of you wants to share how much does your company, or all of you,

how much do your companies need
to invest to get a new employee

just fresh out of the university, up to speed and to be effective
and efficient in
as part of your organization?

Khun Kantima, do you want to get us started?
Or Sheri? I think that from the experience
not only in AIS,

but I think that in our education system, when I talk about education system,
you see that especially in Asia,

our culture also affect
on the way we educate our people.

The good student means the students
who follow what the teacher recommend

and be nice all the time. Those will be
identified as the good student, but the student
who challenged the teacher more,

I think that this needs to be changed
to fit with the private sector needs.

When we look at this,
we see that the new fresh graduate,

the most challenge
is the lack of the experience, like you guys just mentioned,

the lack of experience
in the world of work, the lack of working experience.

They're working on some project
with the student and the teacher, but in terms of
doing the training with the company,

I think the most of the job that's
being assigned to all the student is filing the document,
some company are also doing--

They ask the student to do the copies,
those type of things. So it's not the real experience.

Nowadays I think that things changed. Even in the private sector, old success won't be a good guarantee
for the future success.

So we need to disrupt ourselves,
especially in the education system. I start seeing the collaboration

between the private sector
and the education institutes, the school and the private sector
need to work together

in terms of design the curriculum,
those type of things. The private sector could
step in and help more

to get the student ready to work
in the real world, before they graduate. I used to sit in one meeting
with all the professor,

I noticed that in this room there's
a number of professors listening to this. Mainly we want to
make change on our student,

but we never look at ourselves,
what needs to be changed on ourselves. So I think that's very important.

Before we tell the next generation
what they have to do, we come back and revisit that
what we need to adapt ourselves.

So those will help you to get
the education system, be stronger,

be ready, and then cope with
the fast pace that things change. So that's how I see.

Thank you so much. To me, I think the actual points
on this one is the first thing

is about how to measure the quality of
the student besides them taking the test.

That would be only one dimensional
qualifications about their knowledge.

That's the thing that I think
is quite important from my experience. A good grade doesn't really confirm
that they are going to be a good employee
or the best employees in the company.

That's the first point. And the second point would be the way
they work in the project based learning.

Most of the time the students always work with the similar kind of
knowledge playing in the project,

meaning that they are working
with different in the same technologies or something like that. But in the real world we have
to work with different people,

different knowledge, different experience. For example, in my company, in AP, architects
have to work with the engineers

and also have to work
with marketing team across these two disciplines. That would make them be more
knowledgeable in their area

and they have to share,
they have to open up and collaborate with different thinking. That would help people
become more effective
in terms of work with different people.

For me, I think I totally agree with both. And I think the problem
that I have is that

I have to re-skill the students basically
to onboard them for six months, six months for them to be ready,
for the new grad to be ready for the job.

And also when I look at the grade,
the GPA, the way we evaluate or test the student,

it doesn't have much correlation
with the real performance of the students. Because it takes a lot more
than the subject matter knowledge

to be a very effective
team member of the company, like cultural fit, ability to learn,
ability to communicate,

leadership initiative, that kind of stuff. And also the other thing that we find
is that for subject matter experts,

even students that get a GPA of four
in programming that kind of stuff, and then some of them failed the tests
of cordiality that kind of thing,

because the professional
test it's not the same as the test that they took
in the university. So that's number one.

And number two,
so that's why for KBTG ourselves we're engaged with,
right now, ten universities,

we have a program called KBTG Tech Kampus that we basically reach
out to ten universities

and we work with them to develop
a curriculum feedback on curriculum and also send our team members to
work closely with the professors

and also the students
on doing both core research and also working on a project together
since the third year,

so that student know
where they are better. And it's also kind of like
career guidance as well.

You work on a project for some students. They know that probably they want to
be a data engineer not a data scientist.

I don't want to be a software programmer, but probably I want to be
a cybersecurity guy or that kind of stuff.

So that's what we are trying to do. So basically working closely with
the university to develop a curriculum

and also teaching
and also involve the students early on and also the professor early on,
so that we don't have to risk you.

And because for us it's a big problem.
Imagine this year we get like and trained

actually, 400 new employees
and 400 new employee that they need to ramp up
their skill for six months.
So last year we took the initiative

because in the first year
of COVID last year. So we revamped the whole orientation,
that kind of stuff.

We developed
the whole employee experiences and also the online learning,
that kind of thing,

so the employee can get up to speed much
faster to improve their productivity.

So that's what were trying to do
from KBTG's point of view. Thank you so much for sharing that.

And I'd like to come back in
a second to-- Khun Krating you mentioned

getting involved with the universities
and the professors early on, and I want to come back to that,
but I want to first explore something.

I believe it was Khun Ming who mentioned the measuring the quality
of the students an assessment.

And I wanted to share with everyone
that as part of the ITS program,

the scholars learn a series
of what we call pedagogical levers

or areas where they can really
think about how they design

the learning experience of their students. And there's to the area of assessment
that is incredibly important,
